entries: Fertilized by large quantities of spilled blood, such as that found on bloodstained battlefields or in the war-torn regions surrounding besieged cities, wemmuths are vile swaths of vines that draw sustenance from mortal suffering, lapping up blood like water. Possessing a rudimentary intelligence and an unquenchable thirst for blood, wemmuths lie in wait for most of their lives, growing to incredible size in the bloody soil of their grisly homes. Though the vines that comprise a wemmuth's body are scarcely thicker than rope, a single adult wemmuth system consists of 6 tons of vines, enough to stretch for 6,000 feet if stretched from end to end in a single straight line.

entries.name: Whimwyrm
entries: Whimwyrms are unpredictable dragons native to the whimsically dangerous First World. While their coloration and appearance might evoke reactions of adoration, their moods shift quickly from one extreme to the other. Many who have assumed that their adorability and relatively small size (as far as dragons are concerned) equates to safety have met swift and grisly ends thanks to a whimwyrm's fangs or magic.

A whimwyrm is a slender, sleek dragon, not much longer than 7 feet from snout to tail, but its speed in combat is unnerving. When a whimwyrm attacks, be it with its fanged mouth or its long tail, it makes several quick, darting snaps or lashes at once. These attacks consist of multiple bites or lashings but resolve as a single Strike. A single attack from a whimwyrm can leave a creature covered in tiny but deep bloody wounds.

Whimwyrms prefer to resolve conflicts with jokes or pranks, hoping to achieve a victory over a foe via humiliation without resorting to combat, but any damage or insult sent a whimwyrm's way is a sure invitation for violent retaliation. A whimwyrm's sense of humor vanishes immediately when it is the butt of a joke, or when anyone implies that they missed the point of a whimwyrm's jest or didn't get the punchline.

entries.name: Wild Hunt
entries: The wild hunt is an awe-inspiring and enigmatic group of fey who stalk and pursue their prey between worlds. Those few who have caught glimpses of these elusive beings and lived to tell the tale speak of clouds of green mist filled with spectral hounds, archers who fire bolts of magic with inhuman accuracy, and the sound of a melodious horn echoing for miles across the landscape.

entries.name: Wild Hunt Archer
entries: These lithe, androgynous humanoids have pointed ears, glowing green eyes, and six fingers on each slender hand. They are methodical hunters who fire their bows with uncanny accuracy, and often rely on {@creature wild hunt horse|PKB|wild hunt horses} to provide increased mobility. Rather than carrying normal arrows, they can produce arrows as needed from magical quivers—these quivers do not function in this manner for anyone other than wild hunt archers.

entries.name: Wild Hunt Horse
entries: These powerful steeds stand upon wispy puffs of air, their grassy manes and tails swishing majestically in the wind. When they are not participating in a hunt, wild hunt horses enjoy constructing complicated courses through land and sky and racing each other for ever-changing stakes.

entries.name: Wild Hunt Hound
entries: Wild hunt hounds are intelligent hunters and expert trackers that take the lead against elusive prey. Left to their own devices, they seek out creatures that are notoriously difficult to track. They are always surrounded with green mist composed of fragments of the spirits of the wild hunt's victims, a mystic fog that forms itself into a spectral pack to fight at its side.

entries.name: Wild Hunt Monarch
entries: Each wild hunt follows a wild hunt monarch, who travels effortlessly between the realm of the fey and the Material Plane in search of new quarry. These limber and regal humanoids have elk antlers, long pointed ears, flowing white hair, and luminescent green eyes.

entries.name: Wild Hunt Scout
entries: These compact yet agile humanoids have pointed ears, glowing green eyes, and ram's horns. Wild hunt scouts relish the chance to seek revenge upon those who have wronged or insulted the wild hunt, but they tend to grow bored when the stakes are not lethal. Despite this, they rarely let their bloodlust cloud their judgment when making tactical choices.

entries.name: Will-o'-Wisp
entries: A will-o'-wisp that lingers in a region particularly suited to keeping it well-fed, such as an area under the influence of a tormented soul or other undead haunt, can over the course of decades become a much more powerful variant of its kind. Often, the vague image of a ghostly skull can be glimpsed floating within the depths of an ancient will-o'-wisp's glow.

entries.name: Wolverine
entries: Giant wolverines grow to the approximate size of horses and claim even more expansive territories than their more diminutive wolverine cousins. While a smaller wolverine will defend its prey from armed humanoids, a giant wolverine is unafraid to stalk and kill such creatures.

entries.name: Wraith, Dread
entries: These menacing spiritual remnants of wicked warlords or bloodthirsty generals are towering specters of shadow and death. Like other wraiths, dread wraiths haunt the shadowy places of the world, but dread wraiths are more likely to travel greater distances to sow terror or amass influence, often sticking to dark glades or sinister ruins when journeying across sun-dappled lands. Dread wraiths tends to be arrogant and rarely form a pack with others of their kind, preferring instead to dominate groups of ordinary wraiths.

entries.name: Wyvern
entries: Wyverns are the most commonly encountered drakes within the Stolen Lands, although they tend to prefer the westernmost or easternmost reaches of the region as their hunting grounds.

entries.name: Barbtongued Wyvern
entries: With their long, thorny tongues, these wyverns serve as the favored pets of the nymph queen {@creature Nyrissa|PKB}. As natives of the First World, they are only rarely encountered on the Material Plane. They appear similar to the typical wyvern, save that they have extraordinarily long, barbed tongues that they can use to lash out at victims. Furthermore, their long stay within the supernatural House at the Edge of Time has granted them the ability to hurl barbs from their tongues by snapping the length like a whip; these hurled barbs can pierce through the fabric of reality itself and affix those they strike in place, as if pinning them to the sky.

entries.name: Bloom Wyvern
entries: Wyverns who have been violently spawned from the infected bodies of creatures who succumb to the dreaded bloom curse appear as more colorful, quicker, and simply more "alive" than their lesser kin.

entries.name: Xill
entries: Xills see Material Plane creatures as little more than incubators, but their driving need for fresh hosts never abates, for on their home plane, xills are constantly at war. Only the relative emptiness of the Ethereal Plane keeps their conflict with others from becoming too overwhelming and outpacing the incredible speed at which new ranks of soldiers can replace those who have fallen. These four-armed, warmongering monsters paralyze their victims before implanting them with eggs using an ovipositor normally kept retracted behind their mandibles. Their single-minded drive to expand and conquer is so all-encompassing that while they work together dutifully and without dissent, there is little else in their lives.

Xills have dark red, almost purple flesh, and while many of them wear armor-like clothing made of strange dark material, their supernatural flesh affords them all the protection they need in many environments. Their four arms, elongated faces, twisted jaws, and ropy lengths of tendrils in place of hair leave most scholars with no doubt as to their fiendish natures.

entries.name: Zombie
entries: Zombies might move slowly, but one shouldn't underestimate the danger posed by these ever-hungry undead.

entries.name: Zombie Hulk
entries: Only slightly less dangerous than cyclops zombies, these immense hulking undead foes are nonetheless dangerous creatures that possess terrifying strength. They are typically animated from the remains of huge giants.

entries.name: Zomok
entries: Mighty and mysterious plant-dragons, zomoks prowl the woodlands, defending their homes from destructive forces while healing and restoring their forests following natural disasters and ravaging intruders. Zomoks vary in appearance with the seasons, growing verdant green in the spring and summer, changing to autumnal colors of fiery red and orange in the fall, and decaying to brown in winter. Regardless of the season, though, their general shapes are those of immense, often somewhat rotund-looking dragons. While zomoks can and often do swallow their foes, they have no real need to eat them.

data.name: Chapter 2: NPC Codex
entries: This chapter presents all of the significant, unique NPCs from the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}, be they minor allies, primary villains, unique monsters, or anyone in between. Each of these NPCs is presented with a condensed version of their role in the larger campaign, focusing primarily on their rules. For the full details of their impact in the campaign you'll need to consult the adventures themselves.

Of course, using these statistics for encounters in a Kingmaker campaign is not the only way an enterprising GM can utilize these NPCs. Any of the characters detailed in this chapter can be dropped into ongoing campaigns, either as is or after changing some of their flavor or appearance. The statistics for the legendary lake monster {@creature Hooktongue|PKB}, for example, can become a species of deadly oceanic predator that dwells in a dangerous stretch of sea. The cult leader {@creature Malgorzata Niska|PKB} can be used simply as the rank-and-file priestess for a much larger group of Gyronna-worshipping criminals. Each of these NPCs features suggestions for how they can be used beyond a Kingmaker campaign; feel free to adhere to these recommendations exactly or use them as inspiration for other roles. Even when used against a party who has played through Kingmaker before, simply changing an NPC's name and description can save time when preparing for a game where it's likely that the players will never discover where the idea for the foe came from.

entries.name: Aecora Silverfire
entries: Aecora Silverfire is the leader of the Nomen tribe of centaurs who dwell in the easternmost reaches of the Stolen Lands. You can use Aecora's stats for any Desna-worshipping centaur, such as a potential ally wandering PCs might encounter in the wild. If you do so, though, consider changing her alignment from chaotic neutral to chaotic good, since most worshippers of the goddess of luck and travel are, like her, more kind and forgiving in nature than Aecora is.

entries.name: Agai
entries: Agai is the leader of the Culcheck spriggans, the band who invades the village of Varnhold after {@creature Vordakai|PKB} steals away its people. While Agai can work well in your game as the leader of other spriggan enclaves, he also works well as an unusual member of a rival adventuring party, particularly one based on a composition of more monstrous members than a group composed mostly of humans and other core options.

entries.name: Akiros Ismort
entries: Akiros Ismort is a fallen paladin who joined the {@creature Stag Lord|PKB|Stag Lord's} bandits, but has come to realize that particular lifestyle is even more hollow than he anticipated. His unusual class combination makes him a great choice for any sort of "fallen knight" in your game—someone who has abandoned civilization to live in the wild, perhaps. Whether or not he can be redeemed and returned to his prior faith is left to your party to decide.

entries.name: Akuzhail
entries: Transformed and mutated by the Cult of the Bloom, the warped chimera Akuzhail is now the host of the {@creature bloom of Lamashtu|PKB} {@homebrew |(page 122)}. While you can use Akuzhail as a unique mutant chimera in your own game, you can also use these statistics to represent an entire species of variant chimeras—perhaps a pride of these monsters dwell in the Mana Wastes, or maybe they're genetically engineered creatures that break loose from a buried zoological ship module in Numeria. They could even be used in play as fleshwarp monstrosities from Thassilon, Nexian fleshforges, or drow laboratories, especially if you change their narrative description from that of chimeras with the heads of vultures, centipedes, and rattlesnakes to something even more outlandish.

entries.name: Alasen
entries: The weretiger Alasen can be encountered in {@creature Castruccio Irovetti|PKB|King Irovetti's} palace in Pitax, where she's been staying as a guest. In Kingmaker, she's the leader of the Catspaw Mercenaries, but she can work just as well as the leader of any group of bandits or, even better, a tiger-themed thieves' guild. For a higher level party, you can use Alasen's statistics instead to represent an entire cult or secret society of high-level, deadly weretigers.

entries.name: Ameon Trask
entries: Ameon Trask is one of {@creature Hannis Drelev|PKB|Baron Drelev's} right-hand thugs. He is an unpleasant "pig of a man" who— despite being a poor leader—has been put in charge of one of the first military operations made against the PCs' kingdom. Ameon Trask can also play the role of a bounty hunter or even a specialist in a thieves' guild in other campaigns, as the balance between frontline combatant and stealthy stalker allows him to fit a wide range of villainous roles.

entries.name: Annamede
entries: In the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}, Annamede is meant to be something of a nonviolent foil against the PCs: a bard in the employ of the nation of Pitax. She can play the role of any well-known public performer in your game, and with adjustments to her alignment can fit any sort of position related to entertainment you desire. Her skills also make her an excellent choice to play the role of a spy in your game, be it someone the PCs must defeat or an agent they must ally with. She works best when encountered with allies she can aid.

entries.name: Armag
entries: Armag is one of the primary villains encountered during Kingmaker, but his villainy is in large part the result of influence from the deadly weapon he wields, {@item Ovinrbaane, Enemy of All Enemies|PKB|Ovinrbaane}. During your campaign, you can maintain this relationship between Armag and his sword, or you can replace {@item Ovinrbaane, Enemy of All Enemies|PKB|Ovinrbaane} and simply use Armag as a leader of ferocious warriors. Likewise, you can establish {@item Ovinrbaane, Enemy of All Enemies|PKB|Ovinrbaane} as the goal of a quest; perhaps the PCs race against a rival adventuring group to recover the dangerous sword from a crypt in order to prevent it from giving rise to a new warlord.

entries.name: Auchs
entries: Lumbering and slow-witted, Auchs is one of the more dangerous bandits in the {@creature Stag Lord|PKB|Stag Lord's} employ. With an adjustment to his alignment, though, he can serve as an imposing bouncer at a tavern or even as a lovable rural character who tends to get in over his head.

entries.name: Avinash Jurrg
entries: Avinash Jurrg is the general of Pitax's armies, and in many ways can be considered to be the second-in-command of the nation of Pitax. His unusual heritage makes him a great choice for the final boss of a long-running campaign of your own design, perhaps as the leader of an army of monsters that has been menacing the region for years.

entries.name: The Beast
entries: The enormous owlbear called "the Beast" should in fact carry the name of the PC's kingdom in its name. In your games, the Beast could well be a regional threat to the realm you've chosen as the focus of your campaign, changing its name to "The Beast of Sandpoint" or "The Beast of Falcon's Hollow" or whatever sounds appropriate. Alternately, the Beast's stats could simply serve as those for a particularly enormous breed of owlbears native to a region in your game.

entries.name: Bloom of Lamashtu
entries: A thick, green stalk with spiraling rows of thorns stands at the center of this enormous flowering plant. Each flower has a growing seed pod at its center, surrounded by vibrant petals in a wide variety of colors. Crafted after consecutive seasons of experimentation, prayer, and ritual, the bloom of Lamashtu is the triumph of the cultist {@creature Darivan|PKB} and his Cult of the Bloom. The fiendish plant aids the cult's effort to infect the humanoid population of the Stolen Lands and replace them with monstrous predators.
Cultivated to spread misery and violence, the bloom is quietly malevolent, growing its cursed seeds as rapidly as it can. It stands 12 feet tall and weighs 600 pounds.

While only one bloom of Lamashtu exists in the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}, you can use these statistics for an entire invasive species of abyssal foliage that might spring up in a forgotten corner of your campaign setting. In such a case, the spread of the bloom curse is not so much the result of a cult, but a simple side effect of this alien incursion of inimical plant life into the world.

entries.name: Castruccio Irovetti
entries: King of Pitax, Castruccio Irovetti plays the role of one of Kingmaker's primary villains, a foe whom the PCs learn of and encounter long before their destined fight. He works best in a similar role in other games, perhaps as the leader of a nation of your own design. Consider swapping out his Numerian technology for equivalent magic items if you do so, or alternately lean into this flavor and set him up as an up-and-coming challenger to the rule of a Numerian city.

entries.name: Cephal Lorentus
entries: Once a politician and member of the leadership of Varnhold, by the time the PCs meet Cephal he's likely already transformed into a zombie lord under {@creature Vordakai|PKB|Vordakai's} control. You can use him as a unique undead foe in your game, or even use his statistics to represent an entire new category of undead spellcasters that might haunt a ruined school or university.

entries.name: Chief Sootscale
entries: Chief Sootscale's role in Kingmaker is variable—he could simply be another kobold that the PCs must defeat in combat, or he could become an unexpected ally. In your games, he can certainly play similar roles, but as a kobold rogue you can also use his stats to represent an entire category of specialized and unusual robbers employed by a larger thieves' guild.

entries.name: Corax
entries: The gruff leader of a group of loggers who have found trouble with local fey, Corax is meant to play less of a combat role and instead provide a social encounter with a disgruntled expert. Should a fight break out, however, he's more than capable of protecting himself. You can use these stats for any similar character in your game; simply swap out "logger" from Corax's profession for the occupation of your choice. If you do so, you should also consider replacing or removing his weapons, especially if his new job takes him far away from one that requires him to chop wood! He can also serve as the leader of a group of bandits as well, although if you lean into that role, you should also consider changing his alignment to chaotic evil.

entries.name: Cursed Guardian
entries: This unusual bear guards a long-forgotten shrine of Erastil. You can present the guardian as cursed by other faiths by simply changing the nature of its Accursed weakness so that worshippers of other faiths gain advantage against it. The cursed guardian can be used as a {@creature Alternative Guardian|PKB|particularly powerful species of grizzly bear} in your game by simply removing the Accursed weakness, removing its languages, and reducing its Intelligence score to 2.

entries.name: The Dancing Lady
entries: The Dancing Lady is an evil fey creature known as a baobhan sith; a wicked presence that has settled into a forgotten ruin in the Stolen Lands. You can use these stats for any sinister fey creature in your game—one compelling plot could involve what starts out feeling like a hunt for a vampire but turns into something entirely different.

entries.name: Darg, Fesl, and Urda
entries: These three hill giants seek to take advantage of the growing instability in the Stolen Lands as the threat of war escalates. Of course, these statistics for hill giant fighters also work quite well for hill-giant leaders, or if the party is much higher level, as the rank and file guards in a hill-giant fort.

entries.name: Darivan
entries: Not all cult leaders are clerics invested with the power of a god, and one does not need divine spellcasting to devote their life to a higher power. Darivan is a perfect example as he is a powerful sorcerer who received visions from Lamashtu that compelled him to found the Cult of the Bloom. You can use Darivan's stats for any cult leader associated with some sort of life-giving source of vitality; simply rename his Bloom Regeneration ability as needed and swap out his languages and alignment as appropriate to fit the new role.

entries.name: Davik Nettles
entries: Davik Nettles rose from death as a unique undead creature, and now haunts the site of his murder as a relentless force. If you choose to use these statistics to represent an entirely new category of undead monster, you'll want to adjust the specifics of Davik's rejuvenation to match the lore you build for them. For example, you might create a "river revenant," an undead creature known to haunt the shore of the waterway where it was murdered. Swapping out his ranseur for other types of weapons is another easy way to adjust this stat block to fit other cultures or types of descriptive flavor.

entries.name: Dingetooth and Uurch
entries: These two mitflits are more accomplished than most of their kind, although their choice to focus their efforts on a marble launcher might not be the most efficient use of their training. You can use these statistics for any mitflit gremlin that's managed the luck and skill to live long enough to hone their combat prowess—whether or not you let them keep their marble launcher. Of course, switching the type of damage the marble launcher deals when it hits a target also lets you change the launcher into a glass slinger (slashing damage), a coal flinger (fire damage), or a poison toad-launcher (poison damage).

entries.name: Dovan
entries: Dovan served as the {@creature Stag Lord|PKB|Stag Lord's} second-in-command until recently, but now that this role has been usurped, he's been plotting betrayal. You can use Dovan's stats to serve the role of a typical mid-tier burglar or bandit.

entries.name: Elga Verniex
entries: While the cynical nickname locals have given Elga Verniex, the "Old Beldame," fosters a much more sinister reputation than she actually embodies, she welcomes the privacy it brings her. Her stats work well for any mysterious hermit, but of course, you can lean in to her reputation further by changing her alignment to something more evil if you wish.

entries.name: Engelidis
entries: The spirit naga Engelidis serves as a consort and advisor to {@creature Castruccio Irovetti|PKB|King Irovetti}, but is a dangerous foe on her own. Spirit nagas always make excellent behind-the-scenes antagonists due to their skill at mind control and magic; as such, these stats can serve perfectly for a monster that plays a "power-behind-the-throne" role.

entries.name: Eobald
entries: Eobald's spellbook and other resources have been taken from him. You can certainly expand on these stats to transform him into a standard wizard by adding to his spells prepared, but you also use this stat block as is to represent an imprisoned mage in need of rescue! You can also omit his Spellcasting ability, {@skill Arcana} skill, and other benefits gained from being able to cast wizard spells if you need to introduce an NPC botanist or student of other natural disciplines.

entries.name: Evindra
entries: Once the guardian of the sword, {@i Briar}, the nereid Evindra has remained trapped for many years after the blade was stolen. If the PCs can aid her, she becomes a potent ally. Nereids are a type of aquatic fey with deep ties to water. Although they are primarily aquatic creatures, their unique ability to imbue their vitality into a supernatural shawl allows them to travel on land as well. A nereid must be careful when manifesting a shawl, however, as their life essence is bound to it, so it can be stolen or destroyed to threaten the nereid. A nereid resembles a beautiful humanoid creature with long, pointed ears and webbed fingers.

entries.name: Fredero Sinnet
entries: Fredero once served as a paladin of Shelyn, but he fell from grace when faced with the truth that his method of teaching his students was faulty enough to drive them from the fold.

entries.name: Fionn
entries: Fionn is a very unusual ghost of a very unusual frost giant from the First World. These statistics work best when used for a unique foe in a long-term campaign, where can you tie Fionn's tragic story to one of the PCs' allies, or even to one of the PCs. You can adjust his Bound to the Mortal Night weakness as well to be keyed to other times of the day, month, or even a year.

entries.name: The First Faithful
entries: The First Faithful is the leader of the sinister Kingdom of the Cleansed, but these stats will also serve quite well for a lone priest of an obscure demon lord, perhaps even for someone filling a role like a notorious killer or other lone menace threatening society from its fringes. Remove his Release the Inmost Worms ability if you use these stats outside of his role in the {@i Kingmaker Companion Guide}.

entries.name: Foras
entries: Foras is a powerful sorcerer devoted to the pursuit of bringing the Outer God Yog-Sothoth into this world. You can use these stats for any sort of mysterious leader of a cult or secret society. Remember that as a sorcerer, his powers aren't intrinsically tied to a specific deity or even to a single faith. If you switch the object of his devotion or obsession, you should also consider removing or replacing his Time Siphon and Accelerated abilities with those that are more appropriate thematically.

entries.name: Gaetane
entries: Gaetane is an agent of the nation of Pitax—a wererat ranger who prefers to spend most of his time in hybrid form. He also works as a specialized bounty hunter; you can adjust his favored enemy list to more closely match a party's makeup if you want to use these stats as a hunter hired specifically to track the PCs down.

entries.name: The Gardener
entries: The Gardener is the ghost of a halfling who has long haunted Whiterose Hill in the western Stolen Lands, not far from the city of Pitax. As with most ghosts, his stats are closely tied to his role in the adventure, but they should work well if you need a powerful foe to lurk in a winery, brewery, or even a haunted tavern of your own design.

entries.name: Gedovius
entries: Gedovius plays the role of torturer and jailer in the dungeons of the king's palace in Pitax. He can also be used as a relentless killer who hides in plain sight amid the structures of a beleaguered city, or even as the mysterious leader of a particularly sadistic thieves' guild. To provide a fun change of pace, Gedovius can work well in an adventure where all signs point to a human criminal preying upon a society ill-equipped to deal with them, only to have the PCs discover that, in this case, the predator that has been stalking the city streets is a gargoyle or elemental.

entries.name: Grabbles
entries: Grabbles is the leader of the mitflits who dwell under the Old Sycamore in the Stolen Lands, but works just as well as the leader of a band of any sort of group of gremlins if you wish. Alternately, he could be an unusual loner the PCs might encounter while exploring the wilderness; that rarest of mitflits who is powerful enough to make something of a life on their own. Though Grabbles is lawful evil, that doesn't mean he has to be used as a foe the PCs must fight. He could be given another alignment, or he could be used simply as a pathetic bully the PCs might attempt to redeem or forgive.

entries.name: Grigori
entries: Grigori's role as a provocateur and spreader of propaganda makes him an enemy your players might love to hate, but his statistics can work just as well as the leader of a troupe of actors or a well-traveled entertainer. Adjust his alignment as needed.

entries.name: Gromog
entries: Gromog isn't at his best when he's encountered, as threatening a party of adventures with an ogre during one of their first combats is far too dangerous! These statistics work well for a potential ogre ally the PCs encounter in a dungeon, perhaps a lumbering creature who's been left imprisoned in a cell for many months, or a hapless ogre who's been trapped in a cave by a collapse. In any event, he might have a change of heart and learn to be less awful after being rescued from his plight.

entries.name: Gurija
entries: Gurija is the advisor and consort to {@creature Hargulka|PKB} {@homebrew |(page 140)}. She's not particularly more powerful than a typical troll, but her magical abilities can keep the PCs on their toes if you add her to an encounter where they would not expect to combat sorcery.

entries.name: Hannis Drelev
entries: The baron of Fort Drelev, Hannis is a proud and cruel man destined to become one of the primary antagonists moving against the PCs nation. These statistics work particularly well when used for the role of any petty tyrant or awful king you might wish to unleash upon the party.

entries.name: Happs Bydon
entries: Happs Bydon is a low-ranking member of the bandits working for the {@creature Stag Lord|PKB}. You can use his statistics as the standard version of a member of a larger band of bandits or even to represent a menial guard working for a corrupt government.

entries.name: Hargulka
entries: The troll warlord Hargulka poses an early threat to the PCs' kingdom and might be the first opposing ruler they'll face during the Kingmaker Campaign. These stats can be used to flesh out the ranks of any larger society of trolls in your game, or perhaps to create a specialized gladiator in a city's largest arena.

entries.name: The Hateful Hermit
entries: The hateful hermit is a bitter old man who's lived in the Stolen Lands for longer than he cares to remember. By transplanting him from the wilds to the big city, though, he can play the role of a cruel "beggar prince" or other leader of a small-time gang of criminals. In Kingmaker, the hateful hermit is accompanied by a pet puma he simply calls "Cat." Use the statistics for a {@creature panther|MM} to represent this ally.

entries.name: Hillstomper
entries: Hillstomper once served an elderly druid who granted the mammoth sapience. You can use Hillstomper's statistics for any magically intelligent mammoth— adjusting his alignment, perhaps, to match that of his rider, or even using the stats as the baseline for an entire new species of supernatural steed in your campaign.

entries.name: Hooktongue
entries: The legendary monster of Hooktongue Lake is no myth. While you can use these statistics to represent a standard lake monster, they work best in the role of a legendary creature the PCs have heard rumors about for many sessions before finally facing it in combat.

entries.name: Horagnamon
entries: Horagnamon plays the role of {@creature Vordakai|PKB|Vordakai's} familiar— who acts as a makeshift spy for the lich while the PCs explore the empty village of Varnhold. You can use these statistics for any unusually intelligent raven, of course; he doesn't have to be someone's familiar. Perhaps he's a reincarnated soul, or maybe a unique bird given intelligence by random chance or the influence of the First World.

entries.name: The Horned Hunter
entries: The Horned Hunter serves as one of {@creature Nyrissa|PKB|Nyrissa's} agents, sent to the Material Plane to track down the magic sword {@i Briar}. As a powerful satyr, though, he can certainly play the role of a legendary guardian of an ancient woodland, or even the end boss of a long-term campaign against fey.

entries.name: Ilthuliak
entries: The black dragon Ilthuliak is a legendary monster whose presence has long featured in tales of the Stolen Lands. More powerful than even the standard great wyrm black dragon, these stats can work well when you need a particularly deadly dragon to serve as the primary villain of an entire campaign.

entries.name: Lair Actions and Regional Effects
entries: Illthuliak has the standard lair actions and regional effects of an ancient black dragon.

entries.name: Ilora Nuski
entries: An exile from Pitax, Ilora Nuski can provide the PCs with valuable information about their neighbors— assuming they can gain her trust. You can use Ilora's statistics for a legendary hunter that could become either a friend or foe of the PCs, or simply adjust her alignment as needed to let her serve the role of a guild leader or even the ruler of a rural region.

entries.name: Imeckus Stroon
entries: Imeckus Stroon agreed to take on the role of advisor to {@creature Hannis Drelev|PKB|Baron Drelev} primarily to support his sister, the baroness. As a relatively powerful wizard, Imeckus's stats can serve as the leader of a wizard school or even a patron to a spellcasting PC with a quick adjustment to his alignment.

entries.name: Irahkatu
entries: Most of the ahuizotls (badger-like monsters with grasping hand-like talons at the tip of their tails) that lurk in the waters of Hooktongue Slough are typical members of their kind, but Irahkatu is a particularly powerful (and cruel) monster. You can use these stats as a baseline for an entire species of "greater ahuizotls" in your game.

entries.name: Irovetti's Fetch
entries: Most fetches are relatively similar in power, but in the case of Castruccio Irovetti, his fetch is somewhat different than most other fetch stalkers. If you use Irovetti's Fetch's statistics for another purpose in your game, these stats can be used as an evil version of him that seeks to replace his role in your campaign unless the PCs can stop it.

entries.name: Jaggedbriar Hag
entries: The hags of the Jaggedbriar coven are named Eltrid, Irova, and Vikara. These annis hags seek to enhance their ability to use lesser planar ally with their coven magic. Used singularly, though, this stat block can represent a single annis hag with a slightly different set of spell-like abilities. The Jaggedbriar hag's ability to charm monsters makes a viable foe for use as a diabolical mastermind in your game.

entries.name: Jamandi Aldori
entries: Jamandi serves as one of the first of the PCs' allies: the dueling aristocrat who gathers and recruits the PCs (among others) for the drive to explore and settle the wilderness of the Stolen Lands. Her stats work well for any well-known or even infamous duelist—perhaps a scoundrel who's eager to test her mettle against a PC in a public battle.

entries.name: Jin Durwhimmer
entries: Jin Durwhimmer met his fate in a remote cave in the eastern Stolen Lands while investigating a mysterious link to the First World. As with the other ghosts presented in this chapter, Jin works best when you include him in a plotline that supports his themes, but you can also simply use these stats as a basis for a new type of incorporeal undead that rises from the bodies of druids who lost their faith.

entries.name: Jurgrindor
entries: When the PCs encounter Jurgrindor, the frost giant has been wounded severely. These stats can serve for any frost giant prisoner the PCs might encounter, or if (as in the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}) you narratively need to have a low-level party encounter what's normally a much more powerful foe. Alternatively, you can use a mechanic like Wounded Arm to make any other powerful foe more usable at lower levels, as long as you work to adjust the creature's statistics so that they aren't unfair in a fight at your target challenge rating.

entries.name: Kargstaad
entries: Kargstaad is a four-armed frost giant from the First World—one of the nymph queen {@creature Nyrissa|PKB|Nyrissa's} favored minions. You can explain his four arms any way you wish in your games, of course—perhaps he was influenced by Abyssal energies, was granted his extra arms as a boon from his deity, or was exposed to strange alchemical pollution. You could even have him possess only two arms when first encountered by the party, only to grow the extra two during combat at a suitably dramatic moment.

entries.name: Kereek
entries: The kobold sorcerer Kereek works alongside his friend and ally {@creature Prazil|PKB} as a spy for the troll warlord {@creature Hargulka|PKB}. Kereek is strong for a kobold—he can serve as the leader of a kobold warren in your game, or as a member of a monstrously themed rival adventuring party.

entries.name: The Knurly Witch
entries: The Knurly Witch is one of {@creature Nyrissa|PKB|Nyrissa's} more powerful agents in Thousandbreaths. Her statistics can be used as a great foe or final boss in a campaign whose themes revolve around the sinister cult of Gyronna or other evil deity—after making a few changes to her alignment and domains as appropriate.

entries.name: Kob Moleg
entries: The leader of a band of notorious hill giants, Kob Moleg's alliance with the king of Pitax forces him into conflict with the PCs' kingdom when war between the two nations begins. Kob Moleg is so much more powerful than the standard hill giant that he arguably works better as a unique foe in a campaign than just a clan leader—perhaps he might serve as the primary ruler of all hill giants in an entire region in your game.

entries.name: Korog
entries: Once a faithful worshipper of Pharasma, Korog abandoned his faith and his life as a sacrifice to continue to oppose the works of his brother, the cultist {@creature Foras|PKB}. Of course, in your game, Korog works well as the undead leader of any necromantic army you might create, or as the reanimated legacy of an ancient foe from the past.

entries.name: Kressle
entries: Kressle leads a group known as the Thorn River bandits, and is in the process of becoming a part of the {@creature Stag Lord|PKB|Stag Lord's} greater plan. You can use Kressle's stats as the leader in a group of low-level bandits, or for the bandits themselves if you need a slightly more dangerous group of brigands.

entries.name: Kundal
entries: Kundal is a hunter with a secret: he's a werewolf. Kundal makes for a great foe, especially if you take time in your game to establish him as a member of society before the truth comes out. You can also use his stats to represent the average member of a band of nomadic warriors who have become lycanthropes.

entries.name: The Lantern King
entries: These stats represent an avatar of the Lantern King, the Eldest of trickery. The actual Lantern King would be a much more powerful foe in the CR range of 28–29, but using his avatar allows you to pit him against 20th-level PCs without overwhelming them entirely.

entries.name: Lickweed
entries: Lickweed would have liked to be the leader of his own goblin tribe or warband, but fate had different plans for him. In your game, though, he can perhaps achieve his goal of being the boss himself, rather than serving someone else.

entries.name: Lintwerth
entries: The dust mephit Lintwerth is the familiar of {@creature Imeckus Stroon|PKB} in the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}. You can adjust these statistics to reflect that of any other mephit by adjusting his abilities as appropriate—he doesn't even need to play the role of a familiar if you don't want him to. If not a familiar, he's equivalent to a CR 6 creature (in which case, consider reducing his natural armor bonus by five to adjust his AC to something more appropriate for a CR 6 creature).

entries.name: The Lonely Warrior
entries: The Lonely Warrior is a solo encounter in the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}, but you can use these stats as the basis for an entire category of variant wights to populate a larger, more complex tomb.

entries.name: Malgorzata Niska
entries: Malgorzata is the leader of a small band of Gyronna clerics. You can use these statistics instead for the rank-and-file priests of a larger cult of Gyronna, perhaps using {@creature Sister of the Bloodshot Eye|PKB|Sisters of the Bloodshot Eye} or other Gyronna-linked characters in this book to build an entire campaign focused on opposing this violent religion. Gyronna is a relatively obscure deity outside of the River Kingdoms and the Stolen lands, but within their reaches many fear her cult for she is a cruel deity whose worshippers hold sacred her teachings of extortion, hatred, and spite.

entries.name: Melianse
entries: Melianse is a put-upon nixie who tries her best not to react too violently against the loggers who invaded her home. In your game, she can serve as a much more sinister force. By shifting her alignment to evil she can become an unexpected foe for a lower level series of adventures focused on an entire "cult" of charmed victims acting strangely in a remote riverside village.

entries.name: Minognos-Ushad
entries: Not all dragonslaying adventures require true dragons. Minognos-Ushad is a legendary wyvern of the Stolen Lands, but can equally serve in your game as a storied draconic enemy, particularly if you prefer your dragons to function more as feral beasts than intellectual villains. Alternately, these stats could serve as the basis of an entire species of powerful wyvern.

entries.name: The Misbegotten Troll
entries: The Misbegotten Troll is a violent minion of {@creature Nyrissa|PKB}. She often leaves him to his own devices, which run the gamut from cruel to sadistic. He can just as easily play a role where he is no mere minion. He works well in a game that seeks to tell a Beowulf-style story, where a group of high-level heroes are called upon to save a remote kingdom from attacks by an unbelievably powerful giant.

entries.name: Ngara
entries: Ngara dwells in Hooktongue Slough and has been manipulating the region's boggards and marsh giants for some time. As with {@creature Engelidis|PKB} {@homebrew |(page 131)}, Ngara would work well as the main villain behind the scenes who manipulates a society for her benefit. Indeed, you can use Ngara's stats to represent less powerful serpent agents of {@creature Engelidis|PKB} if she serves as the primary villain of your plot.

entries.name: The Nightmare Rook
entries: The Nightmare Rook looms both figuratively and literally over the realm of Thousandbreaths. This strange, supernatural bird can serve in your game as an unusual primary foe and source of mysterious terrors assaulting a kingdom. The more surreal and strange your encounters get, the better, so that when the PCs finally confront the source of these nightmares, the creature lives up to its name.

entries.name: Nilak
entries: Nilak serves the Six Bears as something of a nontraditional leader, but she's exactly what her followers need to recover from their recent troubles. As a druid, her stats work well for any druid, of course, particularly one who focuses more on combat than passive forms of nature worship. Rather than presenting her as an ally to the PCs, you can also adjust her alignment and flavor text to transform her into a vengeful force of nature who seeks to destroy those who dare encroach upon her domain.

entries.name: Niodrhast
entries: The alien monstrosity Niodrhast has been stranded below Candlemere for centuries, but spent much of that time in hibernation. This creature can also be used as a lurking threat in other ways. They can serve as an ancient menace who remains dormant under an old monastery or other site instead. When civilization encroaches upon Niodrhast's domain, they might wake slowly from their slumber to unleash a vengeful wrath that the PCs will ultimately be forced to quell at the end of a long campaign.

entries.name: Nishkiv The Knife
entries: Nishkiv is the second-in-command of the Black Tears—a group of assassins and thieves that launches an attack at the very start of the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}. As with {@creature Kressle|PKB}, you can use these statistics to flesh out members of a larger band of thieves or bandits.

entries.name: Ntavi
entries: Ntavi's role is to play the part of the bad influence, but with a change to her alignment and personality, she can just as easily play an opposite role as an intimidating but helpful source of advice.

entries.name: Nugrah
entries: Nugrah is a bitter old man. You can use his statistics to play the part of the sinister hermit who isolates himself in the woods. Perhaps he is a cruel-hearted druid, disenchanted or frustrated that the end of his life might soon come before he completes a specific goal. Or maybe he harbors lifelong regrets about a missed opportunity during his youth that now poisons his mind.

entries.name: Nyrissa
entries: Nyrissa serves as the primary villain of the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}. Using her statistics for a foe in another campaign can be tricky, particularly if some of your players have played Kingmaker before. Never underestimate the value of simply changing a foe's name to disguise the origin of its statistics! You can go even further and modify her alignment to good or neutral, perhaps transforming her into a powerful guardian spirit—such as a conscious manifestation of a planet's entire ecosystem. A powerful party of PCs might be called upon to rescue her from even more powerful antagonists bent on enslaving the soul of an entire world.

entries.name: Oleg Leveton
entries: Oleg Leveton is one of the first allies and supporters the PCs meet once they travel into the Stolen Lands. His stats can work well for when you find yourself in need of any local merchant or carpenter.

entries.name: Pavetta Stroon-Drelev
entries: Baroness of Drelev and imperious socialite, Pavetta Stroon-Drelev concerns herself more with excess and comfort than battle. You can use these statistics for a pampered princess, queen, or other upper-class aristocrat, or—after making the appropriate adjustment to alignment and attitude—they can represent a beloved leader or ally. Her dog {@creature Jewel|PKB} might be a different story, though...

entries.name: Phomandala
entries: Phomandala has dwelt in Thousandbreaths long enough to be counted today as a native of the First World. Her powerful nature and magical abilities make her a great choice for a classic tale of a powerful medusa whose reign of terror can be brought to an end only by the most powerful of heroes.

entries.name: Prazil
entries: The kobold spy Prazil works and his ally {@creature Kereek|PKB} serve as agents of {@creature Hargulka|PKB}. Prazil can serve as the leader of a kobold warren in your game, or even as a member of an adventuring party.

entries.name: Quintessa Maray
entries: Quintessa Maray is a Daggermark spy who has convinced {@creature Hannis Drelev|PKB|Baron Drelev} that she is a poor, exiled noblewoman from Galt in need of shelter. These stats work well for any manipulative aristocrat skilled at getting her way and manipulating society with magic and deceit. They can also be used to represent the leader of a renowned theatrical troupe, a famous traveling entertainer, or even as a provocateur intent on destabilizing an evil regime.

entries.name: Rezatha
entries: Among the many triumphs {@creature Castruccio Irovetti|PKB|King Irovetti} boasts, the submission of the deadly remorhaz Rezatha is one of his favorites. You can use Rezatha's stats to represent an entire species of particularly powerful remorhazes to challenge high-level PCs. Or—by simply changing the type of energy damage Rezatha inflicts—you can create an entirely new type of creature native to other realms or planes alike.

entries.name: Rigg Gargadilly
entries: Rigg Gargadilly is a high-strung murderer. While he's encountered in a remote, forgotten ruin in Kingmaker, he'd work well as a supernatural foil against a group of urban-based PCs, for Rigg's talents and predilections would make him a particularly frightening and effective killer. Transplanting him from a remote woodland ruin into the heart of the city gives him an entirely new theme and role in the game without having to change any of his statistics at all.

entries.name: Satinder Morne
entries: Satinder Morne runs The Velvet Corner in Fort Drelev: a gambling hall that can provide the PCs with a (somewhat) safe place to rest during their mission to the hostile town. Her statistics work well for any innkeeper or similar professional who has hidden talents, such as someone who is a retired adventurer or a cleric of a faith whose interests align closely with industry, society, or intrigue.

entries.name: Sepoko
entries: Sepoko is, in theory, the leader of the boggards of M'botuu, but in truth is but a pawn of the naga {@creature Ngara|PKB} {@homebrew |(page 159)}. As a powerful cleric of Gogunta, he can also serve as an unusual cult leader (rather than the pawn of a more powerful manipulator or influencer. Such a mastermind might have moved into the sewers of a large city and attempted to share their faith with members of society's underbelly to form an unusual criminal enterprise.

entries.name: Speartooth
entries: The smilodon Speartooth is the type of legendary creature that many trophy hunters spend their whole lives searching for—and die trying to kill. These stats could be used to represent a creature the PCs are sent to hunt, or alternatively, asked to protect from dangerous poachers. You can also use these stats for a species of hearty saber-toothed-tigers, perhaps pets bred for their ferocity by a clan of even more deadly giants.

entries.name: Spirit of Stisshak
entries: This cruel, manipulative will-o'-wisp has been influencing local lizardfolk for some time. The spirit's ability to appear as a long-dead lizardfolk can be adjusted to give it the ability to appear as anything else you require, such as an ancient-but-revered king, a notorious villain, or even the visage of a deity.

entries.name: The Stag Lord
entries: The Stag Lord represents the first true "boss" of the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}. You can remove the Stag Lord's Perpetual Hangover, restoring him to a CR 7 foe, and have these stats represent an entire group of {@item Stag's Helm|PKB|stag helm}-wearing troublemakers, perhaps led by an even more sinister ruler.

entries.name: Svetlana Leveton
entries: Svetlana Leveton is one of the first allies and supporters the PCs meet once they travel into the Stolen Lands. Her stats can work well when you find yourself in need of a local noble or innkeeper.

entries.name: Tartuccio
entries: Tartuccio meets the PCs early on, but hides his true motives from them as best he can. His skill with illusions and trickery could make him an unusual leader of a criminal organization in a small town, or perhaps as a unique specialist working for an organization with greater reach.

entries.name: Terrion Numesti
entries: When the PCs finally encounter him, Terrion Numesti is a prisoner in need of rescue. These stats work well should you create a rescue mission where the PCs are tasked with locating a relatively high-level NPC and bringing them back alive.

entries.name: Tulvak
entries: Tulvak might strike the PCs as an unusual green hag thanks to her variant spell-like abilities and her disdain of covens. Of course, you can abandon the latter personality quirk to use these statistics to represent the three members of a unique coven of green hags. By swapping out her weapon of choice for another, you can further give a unique spin to this group.

entries.name: Vesket
entries: Thanks to the manipulations of a deceptive will-o'- wisp, the king of the Kamelands lizardfolk, Vesket, grows more cruel with time—drawing treacherously close to fully embracing evil. You can further adjust his alignment as you need depending on the type of lizardfolk king you require for your story. Alternatively, Vesket's stats can be used to represent a member of a rival adventuring group comprised primarily of lizardfolk or other nontraditional ancestries.

entries.name: Villamor Koth
entries: Villamor Koth is something of a local hero in Pitax, despite the fact that he's done little during his violent life that could be considered courageous. He'd work well as a notorious warrior—be he one the PCs face in combat or one whose respect they must earn to recruit his aid against a deadlier foe.

entries.name: Virthad
entries: Virthad is a particularly mean-spirited doppelganger. As a cleric of Lamashtu, their ability to change shape affords them a layer of subtlety that many villains lack. Though Virthad might adopt any guise—such as the goblin priest reflected in their stat block—who they impersonate in your game is defined by your imagination. Their skill at {@skill deception}, however, should help them pose as a member of any faith common to the region in which they reside.

entries.name: Volodmyra
entries: Volodmyra is a mid-ranking member of the Black Tears, and the commander of the attack force sent to invade {@creature Jamandi Aldori|PKB|Jamandi Aldori's} manor at the start of the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}. Her stats work well for any grizzled mercenary, or perhaps even an executioner or torturer in the employ of a cruel overlord.

entries.name: Vordakai
entries: Vordakai is one of the primary villains of the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}: a cyclops lich whose power has atrophied to a shadow of his former glory. As with {@creature Nyrissa|PKB}, he's such a memorable foe that transplanting him into other games runs the risk of breaking verisimilitude for any players who have previously played Kingmaker. That said, you can use his statistics to represent a new type of undead creature based on any Large magic-using humanoid, such as an undead ogre magi.

entries.name: Werendegar
entries: Werendegar is a type of fey known as a gimmerling. His stats work great as is for a completely unique villain from the First World, with his skills and supernatural abilities making him an excellent choice for a doppelganger-like role in a high-level campaign.

entries.name: Windchaser
entries: Windchaser once served an elderly druid who, on his death bed, granted the horse sapience. You can use Windchaser's statistics for any magically intelligent horse—adjusting his alignment, perhaps, to match that of his rider. You can even use his statistics as the baseline for an entire new species of supernatural steed in your campaign!

entries.name: The Wriggling Man
entries: The Wriggling Man is one of {@creature Nyrissa|PKB|Nyrissa's} closest allies—a powerful wizard whose will to live outlasted his original body and continues on in a colony of writhing worms. He works best as a sinister mastermind in other campaigns, and can fill roles classically portrayed by lich warlords or sinister archmages. Due to his terrifying and unusual appearance, introducing him as a villain in your campaign is bound to keep your PCs on their toes!

entries.name: Xae
entries: Xae lost her life in the pursuit of a legendary competition held by one of the Eldest, and lingers after death as a ghost. She works best when the story supports the themes intrinsic to her backstory. However, you can also use these statistics to represent a brand new type of undead in your game, such as an incorporeal spirit who has been untethered from time itself. In this case, consider having Xae come from some strange dimension or other reality from the far corner of the multiverse.

entries.name: Zorek
entries: Zorek is an ageless guardian who watches over a tomb. As a devotee of Gorum, he works best in other games as a guardian of any site sacred to a chaotic god of war—such as a tomb of honored fallen warlords. However, his stats could be used for a guardian of an active shrine or a famous landmark said to have been touched by the god of war in ancient times.
